The garden of Eden cannot be found because it no longer exists. It was destroyed in the global flood.  Yet, here is the general area where it would be found according to the Bible. The garden was toward the east on earth. In other words it was in the eastern part of the earth toward all of the east, even toward the far east. It was in the Middle East. Notice that the garden was “in Eden", which means that it was within and part of the land of Eden, it was not Eden itself. “ planted a garden in Eden, toward the east" Ge 2:8 There was a river that flowed out of the main land of Eden into the garden. Then from the garden the river parted into four rivers. Notice that Moses said there “was a river" flowing out of Eden. So by Moses time there may not have been evidence of such a river, for the flood had changed the topography in the area, and it may have still been actively changing. “There was a river issuing out of Eden to water the garden, and from there it began to be parted and it became, as it were, four heads.” Ge 2:10 Pi'shon was the name of the first river. It probably flowed down the middle of the garden. But change is evident because there was no river by Moses day in the Middle East with this name. Yet God inspired Moses to write about it in the present tense as if it still existed at the time. Perhaps Moses or people of that time knew the location of this river and it's old name even though it and its name had changed. Or perhaps God inspired Moses to record it in the then present tense From his perspective as he saw it then. But, could it be a waterway or river known today by a different name? “The first one's name is Pi'shon; it is the One encircling the entire land of Hav'ilah, where there is gold.” Ge 2:11, 12 The Pi'shon river encircled Hav'ilah, which is traditionally known or thought to be the Saudi Arabian Peninsula. Perhaps this river was the combined waterways of today of the sea of Gal'lee, the Jordan river, the Dead Sea and the Red Sea. Because that would lead to a waterway that would encircle the Saudi Arabian peninsula. Perhaps, in the past, these waterways ran as one continuous river. They may even be linked underground today to some degree. The second river encircled Cush, which is known to be where Ethiopia is, and possibly Egypt. This seems to indicate a waterway from the Mediterranean Sea through the Nile river. “the name of the second river is Gi'hon; it is the one encircling the land of Cush.” Ge 2:13 The third river is more readily identifiable, for apparently only it's name changed. But notice that the verse says “it was going out to the east". So it was going farther east away from where the garden was and from where Assyr'ia was then. The name, though, changed from Hid'dekel to what we know as the Tigris river. “the name of the third river is Hid'dekel; it is the one going out to the east of Assyr'ia. “ Ge 2:14 The fourth river, seemingly, has not changed in appearance nor in name. In is still called the Euphra'tes today. “the fourth river is the Euphra’tes.” Ge 2:14  Other scriptures give more clues as to the whereabouts of the garden. As far north as ancient Tyre, Lebanon to Syria: Is 14:13; Eze 28:2,13, 14, 31:16; Ca 4:15 As far south as ancient Egypt to Zoar (Dead Sea area) area: Ge 13:10; Where ancient Zion (Jerusalem) was: Is 51:3 Eze 36:35 So, basically, the garden was where the ancient promised land of the Hebrews/Iaraelites/Jews was. The boundaries as far north as Lebanon, possibly as far east as toward the Euphra'tes river, as far south as the Dead Sea and as far west as Egypt and Ethiopia. The Hebrew word translated as garden also mean “park", so it was like a large national park the size of a huge country. The garden of Eden, which was a garden from God's perspective, no longer exists today.

The only thing the Bible tells us concerning the Garden of Eden’s location is found in Genesis 2:10-14, “A river watering the garden flowed from Eden; from there it was separated into four headwaters. The name of the first is the Pishon; it winds through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold…The name of the second river is the Gihon; it winds through the entire land of Cush. The name of the third river is the Tigris; it runs along the east side of Asshur. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.” The exact identities of the Pishon and Gihon Rivers are unknown, but the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers are well known. If the Tigris and Euphrates mentioned are the same rivers by those names today, that would put the Garden of Eden somewhere in the Middle East, likely in Iraq. However, even a small local flood can change the course of a river, and the Flood of Noah’s day was more than a localized flood. The Deluge completely changed the topography of the earth. Because of this, the original location of the Tigris and Euphrates is uncertain. It could be that the modern rivers called the Tigris and Euphrates are simply named after those associated with Eden, in the same way that Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, is named after the town in Judea. If the Middle East region is where the Garden of Eden was, and if crude oil is, as most scientists believe, primarily decayed vegetation and animal matter, then it stands to reason that the Middle East is where we would find the greatest oil deposits. Many people speculate that the vast stores of oil in the Middle East are the result of the decomposition of Earth’s lushest organic materials in the Garden of Eden. While the oil in the Middle East could be the dregs of Eden, but those who promote such ideas are simply theorizing. People have searched for the Garden of Eden for centuries to no avail. There are various spots claimed as the original location of Eden, but no one can be sure. What happened to the Garden of Eden? The Bible does not specifically say. It is likely that the Garden was completely destroyed in the Flood. What is the location of the Garden of Eden?

Because God protects it from being found. Read Genesis 3:24 “After he drove the man out, he placed on the east side of the Garden of Eden cherubim and a flaming sword flashing back and forth to guard the way to the tree of life” (Genesis 3:24, NIV). The angel and the sword and the whole place could be invisible so no one can see it, and the angel and the sword prevent anyone from getting there. More likely, it was visible, and perhaps people DID find it before the worldwide flood and were always unable to access it because of the angel and the sword. Indeed, Adam and Eve may have tried to go back many times and were prevented from entering. There are stories to suggest such. The worldwide flood probably mostly destroyed it. Any plants and landscape left there were battered by the flood, unkept for over a thousand years, and part of the later world, no longer a Garden of Eden.

Look at the clues to the “general whereabouts”. A river watering the garden flowed from Eden; from there it was separated into four headwaters. The name of the first is the Pishon; it winds through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold. (The gold of that land is good; aromatic resin and onyx are also there.) The name of the second river is the Gihon; it winds through the entire land of Cush. The name of the third river is the Tigris; it runs along the east side of Ashur. And the fourth river is the Euphrates. (Genesis 2:10–14) As far as I know, there isn’t a clear identification for Havilah. But Cush is an ancient kingdom in Southern Egypt / Northern Sudan / Northern Ethiopia (i.e. a long way south of Israel), and the Tigris and Euphrates are in modern Iraq (and to travel there you go north from Israel, through Lebanon / Western Syria, rather than going east through the desert). The main geographic clues in the text itself point in opposite directions, and to different continents! That rather raises the question of whether the garden was ever intended to be understood as a literal place. Maybe it was, and the whole region was massively reconfigured by the Flood. Or maybe it was only ever meant to be symbolic. In either case, it’s rather tricky to find.

The Garden of Eden is considered to be mythological by most scholars. This means that even specialists consider the Garden of Eden not to be real. Considering that Genesis is derived from Enuma Elish and other Sumerian tales, it is likely that "Eden" comes from the Sumerian word “edin” meaning "plain" or "steppe" ( or the Akkadian word “edinnu”). Because the word “Eden” is closely related to an Aramaic root word meaning "fruitful, well-watered" or to the Hebrew word for "pleasure", Eden may have evolved to become “paradise of pleasure”. Because of the “well-watered” bit, the garden of Eden is usually placed where Tigris and Eufrat come together. If we look closer at the Sumerian myths, the garden paradise of Dilmun was probably inspiration for the Garden of Eden story. The city of Dilmun in the Sumerian story of Enki and Ninhursag, was located in the Persian Gulf, on a trade route between Mesopotamia and the Indus Valley Civilisation, close to the sea and to artesian springs.
